guide.introduction: Need to know what time it is, but don't own a phone, computer, microwave, or any of the other 100 clocks you probably already have? How about a huge mahogany digital clock to prove your geek prowess?
guide.introduction_rendered: Need to know what time it is, but don't own a phone, computer, microwave, or any of the other 100 clocks you probably already have? How about a huge mahogany digital clock to prove your geek prowess?

lines.text: Get some wood. I chose mahogany.
lines.text_raw: Get some wood. I chose mahogany.

lines.text: Create a template for your 7-segment digit.
lines.text_raw: Create a template for your 7-segment digit.

lines.text: Use a scroll saw to cut the LED segments out of the wood.
lines.text_raw: Use a scroll saw to cut the LED segments out of the wood.

lines.text: Use a plunge router to hollow out the back side of the wood.
lines.text_raw: Use a plunge router to hollow out the back side of the wood.

lines.text: Stain the top side of the wood. I used a satin poly.
lines.text_raw: Stain the top side of the wood. I used a satin poly.

lines.text: Connect the digits together using brass tubes and super glue.
lines.text_raw: Connect the digits together using brass tubes and super glue.

lines.text: Get some plexiglass and cut pieces to the shape of the LED segments. (I used the scroll saw for this.)
lines.text_raw: Get some plexiglass and cut pieces to the shape of the LED segments. (I used the scroll saw for this.)

lines.text: Get a few LEDs (I used blue 5mm).
lines.text_raw: Get a few LEDs (I used blue 5mm).

lines.text: Drill holes in the edge of the plexiglass.
lines.text_raw: Drill holes in the edge of the plexiglass.

lines.text: Super-glue the LEDs into the holes.
lines.text_raw: Super-glue the LEDs into the holes.

lines.text: Paint the back and edges of the LED segments with metallic paint.
lines.text_raw: Paint the back and edges of the LED segments with metallic paint.

lines.text: Sand the front of the LED segments. The scratches will diffuse the light.
lines.text_raw: Sand the front of the LED segments. The scratches will diffuse the light.

lines.text: Apply some voltage.
lines.text_raw: Apply some voltage.

lines.text: Take 2 thin sheets of plexiglass and sandwich rice paper between them.
lines.text_raw: Take 2 thin sheets of plexiglass and sandwich rice paper between them.

lines.text: Hot-glue the LED segments to the plexiglass.
lines.text_raw: Hot-glue the LED segments to the plexiglass.

lines.text: Solder wires to all of the LEDs.
lines.text_raw: Solder wires to all of the LEDs.

lines.text: Hot-glue the plexiglass to the inside of the digits.
lines.text_raw: Hot-glue the plexiglass to the inside of the digits.

lines.text: Connect each of the LED segments to a ULN2003A, and a 74HC595 chip. See the schematic. I also added a 220ohm resistor per LED.
lines.text_raw: Connect each of the LED segments to a ULN2003A, and a 74HC595 chip. See the schematic. I also added a 220ohm resistor per LED.

lines.text: Connect the chips to an Arduino and use the time library to "ShiftOut" the time to the 74HC595s.
lines.text_raw: Connect the chips to an Arduino and use the time library to "ShiftOut" the time to the 74HC595s.

lines.text: Stand back (way back) and check the time.
lines.text_raw: Stand back (way back) and check the time.

lines.text: Put it up on your cubicle for all your fellow drones to admire!
lines.text_raw: Put it up on your cubicle for all your fellow drones to admire!

guide.summary: How to make a 4-foot-long digital clock using mahogany, rice paper, LEDs, plexiglass, 74HC595 and ULN2003 chips, and an Arduino.
guide.title: 4-Foot Wooden Digital Clock
